fields.description:
As can be seen from JRA-26028, the current wording of this link (see attached screenshot) is extremely misleading...

It currently implies that *Application Links* are configured through this feature, whereas only *Project/Entity Links* (of PRE-CONFIGURED Application Links) are only configurable via this link.

As mentioned on the [Managing Global Permissions|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+Global+Permissions] page of our docco:
* *Application Links* are only configurable by users with the *JIRA System Administrators* global permission.
* *Project Links* can be configured by users with either the *JIRA System Administrators* or *JIRA Administrators* global permission.

Hence, users with the *JIRA Administrators* global permission (but not *JIRA System Administrators*) viewing the Project Summary page (in JIRA admin mode) may think they can configure an app link when they can't.

(Incidentally, thanks to [APL-668|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/APL-668] being fixed, the wording on the target page of this link is correct.)

h4. How to fix this issue - very easy!

In the JIRA source code, change the following property in the file *JiraWebActionSupport.properties* from:
* {{admin.projects.configure.application.links=Configure Application Links}}
TO
* {{admin.projects.configure.application.links=Configure Project Links}}

NB - Please leave {{admin.projects.application.links=Application Links}} 'as is' to indicate that configuring a 'project link' is part of configuring an 'app link' - i.e. I suspect a user will get confused if they see only 'Project Link' out of context (with no reference to Application Links).
fields.summary: On the Project Summary page (in JIRA admin mode), change the 'Configure Application Links' link wording (which is misleading and incorrect) to 'Configure Project Links'.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-26029].
  {panel}

Hi there, 

It is very frustrating when doing a bulk search on issues but not having sub-tasks appear immediately under their related issue.

I'm just wondering if you have considered adding either a sub-key, or changing the format of the key so that subtasks are displayed directly under their related issue after a search where the sort order is on the key.

As a suggestion, if I create an 'issue' which is given a key of "DEMO-1", can sub-tasks incorporate this key in some way rather than being given their own, unrelated key?

For example:
DEMO-1-1	first sub-task
DEMO-1-2	second sub-task

If the order of these sub-tasks is changed within the issue, then the key should change to reflect that.

h2. complaint from our users: {quote}I don't want a notification email when someone else gets assigned{quote}
{quote}
Is it really important to send this kind of mails?
I am not watcher, nor in copy to, not reporter.
So the reason I received this mail, was because I was Assignee, but not anymore and someone else has changed that.
So I don't have to do anything anymore,
so I should not receive this update from JIRA by mail:
{quote}
{code}
----- Forwarded by LV@.... on 31/07/2011 11:27 -----
From:	"SH (JIRA)" <noreply@...>
To:	LV@...
Date:	28/07/2011 23:10
Subject:	SILKROAD Assigned: (SR-1329) Main icons - Blue




     [ http://..../browse/SR-1329?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:all-tabpanel ]

SH reassigned SR-1329:
------------------------------------

    Assignee: JB  (was: LV)

...
{code}



h2. Proposed solution
I think the email notification scheme needs to be extended to the user profile & so that users can select which events they want to be notified of. Ideally these settings should also allow for conditional rules. (such as the above mentioned _unless issue is already "In Progress"_ )

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-26022].
  {panel}

I wanted to share some feedback on JIRA especially as it relates to how we're prioritizing work between the Business and our IS department. I've set up a filter that pulls a view together from multiple projects that each have many tasks.

Among those projects we have an overall business priority and it would be awesome if I could edit that business priority directly in the table view provided in the above filter. I'm looking for a process like 1) Click on a cell to edit, 2) Make changes and hit enter to save, and records re-order based on sorting set. 

Right now the process is more like 1) Ctrl+Click a task to open it in a new tab from the filter view, 2) Click the edit link on left, 3) Change business priority, 4) Hit save button, 5) Close new tab, 6) Continue editing the filter view or hit refresh to see changes.

It seems like this would be a much easier way to enter data across multiple projects.

Thanks much, -Matt

fields.description:
h3.Symptoms

After translating your instance to French, when you go to the Issue Navigator and click "Tools", you see "Bulk Change" replaced with "Changement en lot :". The break line char   is not recognized.

!translation_error.png!

h3.Work around

# Shut down your JIRA instance.
# Go to _<JIRA_INSTALL>/atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/lib_ and open the file *jira-lang-fr_FR-4.4.1.jar* with an archive manager tool as 7zip.
# Inside this file, you will see two folders. Roll to _/com/atlassian/jira/web/action/_ and open the file *JiraWebActionSupport_fr_FR.properties* with a text editor tool.
# Search for the line *admin.global.permissions.bulk.change=* and you will see the text "Changement en lot :".
# Replace this line with *admin.global.permissions.bulk.change= Changement en lot:*, save any change and update the file *jira-lang-fr_FR-4.4.1.jar*.
# Finally, start your instance again and check if the issue is gone.
fields.summary: Error in the french translation package confirmed from latest JIRA versions

fields.description:
Browser seems to hang after a certain sequence of actions.

Steps to reproduce:
* open issue
* click "Comment"
* type something, but don't click "add"
* click a workflow-action
* navigation-warning appears ("are you sure")
* click "cancel"

Now the browser shows an animated -waiting-gif superimposed over greyed issue.
Users perceive this as "hang". Actually, the browser has hit a javascript-error and did therefore fail to remove the waiting gif or refresh the page. The workflow-transition has in fact happened.
fields.summary: browser hang on starting workflow-action while commenting

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-26006].
  {panel}

When creating a permission scheme from a scratch, it is needed to set a lot of permission allowances for different user types/groups.
 It takes time to go through all the options adding the permission rules one by one.

Example:
You wish to grant 'create attachments' permission for the reporter, project lead, current assignee and 3 distinct groups.
This requires you to scroll down to the create attachment (or select it from the list on the 'Add New Permission' screen) on the 'edit permission scheme' click 'add' and then on the new screen select 'reporter' and click 'add'. After clicking 'add' the view is returned back to 'edit permission scheme' screen, scroll position being at top of the page (a minor annoyance, it could return to same scroll position as when the 'add' was clicked). Then you need to do the cycle again for adding the permission for project lead, current assignee and once for all the 3 groups.


Could it be possible to make an improvement, where you could use checkboxes (instead of radio buttons) in screen 'Permission Schemes' > 'Add New Permission' to be able to select multiple options at once.
 Also changing the single select menus (atleast the group menu) into a multi select menus would be helpful.

(See the attachment)

I understand there already is a similar request, but I thought I could provide a bit more information by creating a new one.
JRA-1390 << The related issue

fields.description:
*Short Description*
I can see what any other user has voted on or is watching (even if I don't have the View Voters and Watchers permission) by changing my profile's "Full Name" to be the same as theirs and then executing a query {{voter = 'John Smith'}} or {{watcher = 'John Smith'}}.

*Long Description*
Issue JRA-18436 introduced the "voter" function for searching.  For this to work, it requires the user executing the query to have the "View Voters and Watchers" permission, otherwise they can only see what they've vote on. So {code}voter = 'David Hergert [PAETEC]'{code} works as expected; shows me only issues I've voted on.  If I execute that query with any other user's name, I get no results.

But if I change my Full Name in my profile to be "Matt Quail [Atlassian]", and execute {code}voter = 'Matt Quail [Atlassian]'{code}, I can see everything Matt has voted on, which essentially side-steps the View Voters and Watchers permission.
fields.summary: Anyone can see which issues any other user has voted/watched by changing their profile Full Name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25994].
  {panel}

The footer of the JIRA documentation links people directly to support.atlassian.com to get help.  This needs to be updated to point to a page with instructions instead:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Getting+Help

There are also a range of textual references to create a support request on support.atlassian.com that need to be updated for 4.4 and 4.3.

I realize this is a lot of grunt work, but direct linking to SAC bypasses the Support Tools Plugin, which is designed to give us all the information we need to help customers and improve the quality and speed of Support.
fields.summary: Direct links to SAC need to be replaced...

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25991].
  {panel}

This seems to have been asked by JRA-14425 back in 2008, but at the time the Labels were a separate plugin, and I wasn't able to find whether this had been resolved as the links went to the LBL project, which I suppose was removed when the labels were included in the base JIRA software.

We are using JIRA 4.1.2, so if this has been fixed in a more recent release, that is fine too, but at the moment it isn't working as described in the documentation.

Our organization's usage prevents us from being able to give every user 'edit issue' permission (right now there are 5 people who have edit permission), but we would like to be able to broaden the scope of who is able to label issues (everyone would work, or even just have a separate permission we can add project roles to).

In the documentation there was no mention of any permission settings for the ability to edit/add/remove labels from issues, but I found the previously mentioned JRA-14425 which suggested that the permission was tied to the edit issue (which we've had to restrict).  This is consistent with the behavior we have seen here (those without the edit issue permission cannot add/edit/remove labels).

Thank you,

Casey
fields.summary: Separate permission to create/edit labels from edit issue permission

Hey Guys,

So, currently in JIRA you can select the Directory when you are creating users and groups. However, once you create them in the diretories, you cannot change this setting anymore. 

By implementing this, the users can easily solve almost any problem that might've occured during an upgrade, as well giving them the oportunity to change this setting on runtime, instead of having to do the upgrade again, or via database hacks.

Cheers
Thiago Prisco

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25973].
  {panel}

h3. Description

On the View Issue screen, the Workflow button is disabled unless the maximum number of workflow items has been exceeded.

However, if the maximum is exceeded by one, the Workflow button only has one menu option.

Instead of showing the Workflow button if there is only one option, just show the extra option.  

I realize this has a few extra implications:

* Should the Workflow button just be hidden instead of disabled when it is not in use?
* What should the max actually represent?  Max buttons including the workflow button?

h3. Example

*In current scenario*, given transitions of Start, Resolve, Close, Confirm for a given status and a Max workflow buttons of 3, you would get:

|Start|Resolve|Close|Workflow \\ Confirm|

*In the suggested scenario*, given the transitions of Start, Resolve, Close, Confirm for a given status and a Max workflow buttons of 3 you would get:

|Start|Resolve|Workflow \\ Close \\Confirm|

but a Max workflow buttons of 4 you would get:

|Start|Resolve|Close|Confirm|

h3. The Benefits

The benefits would be:
* No wasted space when Workflow button not needed (because it would be hidden)
* No extra click when only one menu item

h3. Extrapolate

This obviously could be applied to Action buttons (though I don't know if I've ever seen the action list small enough to not need the "More Actions" button) and any other place this menu concept is used.
fields.summary: If "Workflow" button on View Issue screen only has one menu item, just show the item with no "Workflow" dropdown

fields.description:
If a workflow step is configured in the Workflow Designer to only have a global transition out, then no transitions appear in the workflow buttons on the issue's screen.

Bug found by adding a global transition (Cancel) to a Cancelled status.  All workflow steps except one (Cancelled) have at least one other normal transition out to another step.  They all show their normal transitions and the global transition.  Cancelled has a transition out to a step called "Edit (after Cancel)".  It was assumed that the global Cancel transition would show up so the user can return the Issue to Cancelled.  However, in practice, if the user transitioned to "Edit (after Cancel)" then the Issue was stuck there with no workflow step available.

This was fixed by noticing that "Edit (after Cancel)" was the only step with no normal transition out.  Moreover, even though there was a global transition in place, "Edit (after Cancel)" could not have any transitions added in draft, suggesting that Jira was ignoring the global transition when deciding on the rules about how to handle a step with no normal transitions out.  It was fixed by taking a copy of the workflow, then adding a circular transition from "Edit (after Cancel)" back to itself and hiding it with a condition.  Then a new workflow scheme was created, and the copy of the workflow added to it, and the scheme applied to the relevant projects.  

Once that was done, the global transition Cancel re-appeared as a workflow button on the Issue screen.

*Replication Step:*
# Copy the default workflow
# Add a new status/step(eg. Test) with an incoming transition(eg. to Test) but no outgoing transition from that step
# Add a global transition to Closed step(eg. to Close)
# Create a workflow scheme(eg. test scheme) and associate to this workflow
# Associate the "test scheme" to a project
# Create new issue and transition to Test status.
# There will be no outgoing transition in Test step.

*Workaround:*
adding a dummy transition with a "Hide"condition then allows the global transition to appear.
fields.summary: If a workflow step only has a global transition out, no transition is available in production.  (Workaround suggested in Description)

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25954].
  {panel}

When a potential user clicks on a link to create an issue and is not logged in, they see the following message:

Errors

You are not logged in, and do not have the permissions required to create an issue in this project as a guest.

To create an issue first log in

And the `log in` text is a link (but not underlined as links usually are).

Why doesn't this page just show a login required screen like /browse/[PROJECT] does? Or better yet, show the actual login with the os_destination set?

We've had some folks who misinterpret the error notice and think they can't create an issue, which then leads to unusual emails and error reports and sometimes angry/baffled users. All because the message is telling them something they don't understand. Why not just do the login redirect for them?
fields.summary: Show the login screen when user attempts to create an issue and is not logged in

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25953].
  {panel}

As a member of Bamboo team, I am subscribed to email notifications for all events occurring within Bamboo project - issue creation/comments etc.
That's quite a lot of emails, but I try to read/skim them all - eventually.
My problem is that not all of these emails are equally important - comments on the issues I've been assigned too, participated in or created are much more important than others.
Up to June/July, JIRA email notifications contained a small header that included the information about assignee etc. - I've applied mail filters to this header
to redirect the really important mail into my main mailbox. With the new comment format, it's no longer possible.
So, my question is - is it possible to put this information back into the notification email? In case of HTML emails, it doesn't even have to be displayed, just included in the HTML body as a comment.

  {panel}

Hello Team,

So, the steps to reproduce are pretty straight-forward:
- Integrate JIRA with Crucible
- On a comment, refer to a Crucible issue (for instance, CR-TEST-73)
- JIRA will render the comment, and make the TEST-73 a link to a JIRA issue, whether making the whole string an link to the Crucible issue.

As there is no way to even disable the automatic linking, the above steps will make every comment which relatest to an existing issue key a link. The only workaround is to make the comment as a wiki comment, or encapsulate the comment (using \{code} for instance).

Is there any plans to make the automatic issue liking optional, and switcheable?

Cheers

Thiago Prisco

From https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-25304?focusedCommentId=273346&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-273346

On Ubuntu server when starting or stopping:
/opt/atlassian/jira/bin/setenv.sh: 97: pushd: not found
/opt/atlassian/jira/bin/setenv.sh: 100: popd: not found

This is because /bin/sh is pointing to /bin/dash by default (and dash doesn't support pushd & popd).
I was able to fix it locally using:
sudo unlink /bin/sh && sudo ln -s /bin/bash /bin/sh
but hopefully there's a nicer way to implement it.

  {panel}

On Ubuntu server when starting or stopping:
/opt/atlassian/jira/bin/setenv.sh: 97: pushd: not found
/opt/atlassian/jira/bin/setenv.sh: 100: popd: not found

This is because /bin/sh is pointing to /bin/dash by default (and dash doesn't support pushd & popd).
I was able to fix it locally using:
sudo unlink /bin/sh && sudo ln -s /bin/bash /bin/sh
but hopefully there's a nicer way to implement it.
fields.summary: Issue with setenv.sh when starting and stopping JIRA on ubuntu

In the "Issues in progress" and "Assigned to me" gadgets, the "Log work" button doesn't do anything on Firefox 7.0.1.

fields.description:
{panel}
h3. Status

OK The problem with this bug is that JIRA is working as intended.

When JRA-6344 was implemented, we changed JIRA to *always* send a notification to the old assignee when the assignee changed, regardless of what Issue Event was fired as configured in the applicable Notification Scheme or Workflow.

In addition, we added this configuration property, {{jira.assignee.change.is.sent.to.both.parties}}, which allowed users who didn't want this new behaviour to have the old behaviour instead by setting the property to {{false}}.

That (old) behaviour is as follows: If the assignee is changed, then the old assignee will be notified of the change ONLY *in response to an Issue Assigned Event*. When an issue is edited (as opposed to "assigned"), and the assignee is changed, then the old assignee will NOT receive the notification. 

Note that events that are fired as a result of workflow transitions are customisable, they can be edited in post functions for workflow transitions.

While it's perfectly reasonable to expect JIRA to not send a notification with this property set, we are still considering this as it will result in changed behaviour for existing customers who may be relying on it. 
{panel}

The application properties in this case is _jira.assignee.change.is.sent.to.both.parties_. 

User wanted to disable this properties from sending notification out to previous assignee but the properties doesn't work when they make changes through jira-config.properties.

To ensure it works, user have modify the default value of the application properties from True to False via jpm.xml, however it is not working.

The documentation have stated this properties still works in latest JIRA version:[Creating A Notification Scheme|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Creating+a+Notification+Scheme#CreatingaNotificationScheme-AboutEmailNotifications]

p/s: user restart JIRA instance each time after any modification happens in jira-config.properties and jpm.xml.
fields.summary: "jira.assignee.change.is.sent.to.both.parties" Properties doesn't take effect after modify via jira-config.properties and jpm.xml.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-25924].
  {panel}

With fine-grained automated "External User Management" control, it will be useful in some set ups to allow admin to set the Internal Directory as enabled but read-only.

In particular if most your User management is done through a read-only LDAP or Crowd server, it is actually good practise to leave at least one System Admin user in the Internal Directory.
This user is used to edit the settings for the LDAP directory, and also in case of emergency if the LDAP server is no longer reachable (eg it changes IP address / port number etc).

Currently this means that JIRA has to assume that User Management is in general "writable", so it shows the "Forgot Password" link on the login page, there is an "Add User" button on User Browser etc.
Being able to set the Internal Directory to Read-Only would fix this.
fields.summary: Allow configuring the Internal Directory to be "Read Only"
